title: 105_s2545
content: The "Medicare HMO Protection Act of 1998" allows for the evaluation and alteration of termination decisions. Section 1851(g)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended to allow the Secretary to delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice organization's plan if it poses a serious risk to enrolled individuals' health. The Secretary can delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice organization's plan if it poses a serious risk to enrolled individuals' health or significantly reduces available plans in the affected area. The Secretary can delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice organization's plan if it poses a serious risk to enrolled individuals' health or significantly reduces available plans in the affected area. This includes situations where the organization offers plans in close proximity to the affected area without suffering financial losses. The Secretary may audit and inspect organization's books or records to determine termination without significant financial losses. The Secretary can end a delay before the established period. The Secretary can end a delay before the established period if an adequate provider network is established to provide equal insurance coverage. The Secretary can end a delay if an adequate provider network is established to provide equal insurance coverage. If the termination is delayed, the Secretary and the Medicare+Choice organization may renegotiate the contract. The Secretary can delay termination to negotiate a new contract with the Medicare+Choice organization under section 1857 to ensure beneficiaries are not negatively impacted. SEC. 3. Extension of initial Medicare+Choice contract period to 3 years. Amends the Social Security Act to require contracts to have a term of at least 3 years. Effective for contracts entered into after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. Notice of termination. Section 1857(d)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended to require Medicare+Choice organizations to provide written notice 120 days before contract termination, including alternative benefit options for enrolled individuals. The amended Section 1857(d)(3) of the Social Security Act requires Medicare+Choice organizations to give written notice 120 days before terminating a contract, including details on available Medicare+Choice plans, medicare supplemental policies, and their costs in the area, along with a local social services telephone number. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to any notice of termination provided on or after the date of enactment of this Act.
